title: EU consumers back call for more stringent eco-labels on confectionery and other food products - ConfectioneryNews.com
summary: The European Commission is considering measures to eliminate misleading environmental claims, including a universal 'Product Environmental Footprint' label backed by consumer support. A survey revealed that a significant majority of European consumers believe food brands exaggerate their sustainability claims, indicating widespread demand for clear eco-labels. The lack of international standards for sustainability labeling leaves consumers confused about the environmental impact of food products. The Consumer Observatory aims to empower consumers and promote a sustainable food system through better insights and knowledge.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article discusses the potential for a standardized eco-label aimed at reducing misleading environmental claims, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: FALSE - While it discusses regulatory proposals and consumer insights, it does not present a new or improved product or business process.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not explicitly mention a specific green product.
green_process: FALSE - Although it discusses eco-labels, it does not outline a specific green process.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541620 - Environmental Consulting Services; 541910 - Marketing Research and Public Opinion Polling; 812910 - Pet Care (except Veterinary) Services; 311999 - All Other Miscellaneous Food Manufacturing.
greenwashing: FALSE - The article critiques misleading environmental claims and supports initiatives for clearer labeling, indicating a focus on accountability rather than deceptive marketing.

title: Nestlé invests £7 million into new hard-to-recycle plastics plant - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Nestlé has invested £7 million in Impact Recycling to develop a new recycling facility in the UK aimed at processing hard-to-recycle plastics used in food packaging. The new technology, known as Baffled Oscillation Separation System (BOSS), will sort and recycle flexible plastics into reusable pellets that can be made into new products. The initiative aligns with the UK government’s waste reduction strategy and Nestlé's goal to improve its packaging practices and recycling systems, striving for 100% of packaging to be recyclable or reusable by 2025.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation as it focuses on reducing the environmental impact of hard-to-recycle plastics through recycling technology and infrastructure development.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation because it involves a new partnership and investment in advanced recycling technology that differs significantly from the firm's previous processes.
green_product: FALSE: While the process addresses plastic waste, it does not describe a specific green product but rather focuses on the recycling process and technology.
green_process: TRUE: This is a green process because it involves innovative technology to recycle hard-to-recycle plastics, reducing waste and promoting sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325211 - Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing, 321920 - Wood Container and Pallet Manufacturing, 332999 - All Other Miscellaneous Fabricated Metal Product Manufacturing, 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not exemplify greenwashing as Nestlé is actively investing in genuine solutions for environmental sustainability rather than making false claims.

title: PepsiCo pushes entrepreneurial collaboration as 'vital' APAC sustainability strategy - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: PepsiCo has launched the Greenhouse Accelerator Programme in the APAC region to support entrepreneurs developing sustainable solutions, including carbon capture technology by Powered Carbon. This programme aims to foster innovation in sustainable packaging and climate action, highlighting its commitment to net-zero objectives. Powered Carbon was awarded a grant to refine its eco-friendly fertiliser project, which utilizes carbon dioxide, benefiting potato cultivation in PepsiCo’s supply chain. The initiative showcases collaboration between PepsiCo and start-ups to drive meaningful change in sustainability.
green_innovation: TRUE: The initiatives described in the article involve efforts to address sustainability challenges and reduce environmental impacts, particularly through innovative technologies that utilize carbon dioxide to create eco-friendly fertilisers, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE: The article discusses a new initiative (the Greenhouse Accelerator Programme) by PepsiCo that aims to develop new sustainable products and business models, which aligns with the definition of business innovation.
green_product: TRUE: The eco-friendly fertiliser produced by Powered Carbon, which utilizes carbon dioxide and aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions compared to traditional fertilisers, fits the definition of a green product due to its reduced environmental impact.
green_process: TRUE: The process of utilizing carbon emissions to produce the eco-friendly fertiliser exemplifies a green process as it minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability.
product_or_process: Powered Carbon's eco-friendly fertiliser production process
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325311 - Fertilizer Manufacturing, 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology), 311411 - Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing, 322213 - Paperboard Container Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not suggest any misleading claims about the environmental benefits of PepsiCo's initiatives. Instead, it describes a genuine effort to innovate in sustainable practices and support entrepreneurs working towards environmental goals.

title: Global Denim Jeans Strategic Market Report 2023-2030 - Denim Enters Dynamic Times with Innovations to Push ... - GlobeNewswire
summary: The global denim jeans market is projected to grow from $70.1 million in 2022 to $114.6 million by 2030, with a CAGR of 6.3%. The analysis includes offline and online sales channels and covers market growth in various regions, with specific forecasts for the U.S. and China. Additionally, the report highlights the importance of sustainability trends and innovations within the denim industry.

title: Mars rethinks recipes, ingredients on journey to Net Zero - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Mars Inc. aims to achieve net zero emissions across its full value chain by 2050, with a roadmap to reduce emissions by 50% by 2030, primarily focusing on sustainable sourcing, ingredient innovation, and reformulation. Key initiatives include developing lower GHG-footprint ingredients and collaborating with third-party suppliers to create sustainable alternatives. The company is also investing in improving its current ingredients' sustainability and considering climate impact during acquisitions. Mars has partnered with UC Davis for breakthroughs in producing a natural sugar substitute, allulose, and is trialing dairy alternatives through precision fermentation.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because it involves developing sustainable ingredients and processes that significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and environmental impacts, thus supporting environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation because it encompasses new product development and improved processes that differ significantly from Mars' previous offerings, introducing them to the market.
green_product: TRUE: The development of allulose as a natural sugar substitute is a green product because it offers a healthier alternative to traditional sugar with a reduced environmental impact during its production.
green_process: TRUE: The precise fermentation process used to produce allulose and the utilization of sustainable ingredient sourcing and production methods constitute green processes as they minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311 chocolate and confectionery manufacturing, 3121 dairy product manufacturing, 325 food manufacturing, 3119 other food manufacturing.
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not suggest greenwashing as Mars Inc. is actively pursuing measurable environmental goals with tangible innovations and partnerships that enhance sustainability rather than making misleading claims.

title: Top 10 Best Paper Manufacturing Companies In India 2024 - Inventiva
summary: The article discusses the evolution of India's paper manufacturing industry, highlighting the top 10 companies that have embraced innovation and sustainability amidst rising demand for paper products. These companies have adapted to environmental concerns by implementing eco-friendly practices and advanced technologies for efficient production. Their commitment to quality, sustainability, and customer satisfaction positions them as leaders in the market, contributing to both economic development and environmental preservation. The article also outlines potential strategies for future growth, emphasizing the importance of sustainability and technological advancement.

business_innovation: TRUE, because the companies mentioned have introduced new or improved manufacturing processes and products that significantly differ from their previous offerings, meeting the criteria for business innovation.
green_product: TRUE, because the article indicates that the products produced by these companies, such as eco-friendly papers and packaging solutions, are designed to minimize environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE, because the article describes manufacturing processes that focus on sustainability, reduce resource consumption, and implement energy-efficient technologies.
